title: Powerful storm triggers flooding and power outages in T.O.
authors: ['Bryan Passifiumemore Bryan Passifiume', 'More Bryan Passifiume', 'Supplied', 'Published', 'July', 'Updated', 'Pm Edt Filed Under', 'Toronto Sun', 'News', 'Toronto']
text:
Those living in the city‚Äôs west end spent the afternoon cleaning up after a powerful storm that swept through the area.

Weather radar shows the storm cell popping up around 2:30 p.m. over southwestern Vaughan, growing in intensity as it tracked south between Allen Rd. and the 427.

I advised the first car to turn around. Figured the truck would follow suit but it went for it. #torontostorm pic.twitter.com/ji374odt1x ‚Äî Sannah Choi (@SannahChoi) July 8, 2020

That triggered a Special Weather Statement from Environment Canada, warning of heavy rains and the possibility of flooding.

The advisory was soon upgraded to a Severe Thunderstorm Warning, as the storm unleashed torrents of rain, strong winds and frequent lighting.

As the storm neared Lake Ontario, localized rotation prompted Environment Canada to also issue a Tornado Watch, which was rescinded about 10 minutes later as the rotation weakened.

Busy afternoon for Toronto Fire with a plethora of storm/wind/flooding related calls ‚Ä¶. rescues, wires down, elevator rescues, water complaints. #onstorm pic.twitter.com/NSCcI0QjZg ‚Äî ùô±ùöõùö¢ùöäùöó ùôøùöäùöúùöúùöíùöèùöíùöûùöñùöé (@BryanPassifiume) July 8, 2020

Wind gusts approaching 100 km/h were possible along the storm‚Äôs western fringes, Environment Canada said.

Videos and images shared to social media showed flooded streets and parking garages, trees knocked down and downpours reducing visibility to near zero.

As of 4 p.m., sporadic power outages were spread across the city‚Äôs western regions, according to Toronto Hydro.

‚ÄúCrews are making progress with restoring power across the city,‚Äù Toronto Hydro tweeted at around 6 p.m. ‚ÄúCrews are focused on safety emergencies first including downed wires and trees on wires.‚Äù

Dang, why spend $$$ on a wedding photographer when you can just screen grab from the Humber River at Old Mill gauge station camera? Running high after this afternoon's Toronto storm, as seen from @TRCA_Flood slick new gauging site https://t.co/Ww8R3XdEbL #onstorm https://t.co/UfHLbVPztq pic.twitter.com/VL8QzXuxQE ‚Äî Jacob Bruxer (@JacobBruxer) July 8, 2020

Toronto Fire was also kept busy in the storm‚Äôs aftermath, responding to more than 40 separate storm-related calls at its peak ranging from elevator rescues to wires down.

title: April showers, and cold, will hopefully bring May flowers
authors: ['Kevin Connormore Kevin Connor', 'More Kevin Connor', 'Veronica Henri Toronto Sun Files', 'Published', 'April', 'Updated', 'Pm Edt Filed Under', 'Toronto Sun', 'News', 'Toronto']
text:
April has been a disappointment in many ways, including the weather.

We have had the odd snowstorm and crazy high winds. The daily average temperature should be 7.1C but it has been 4.9C.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs cold and below normal. We are about two degrees off,‚Äù said Gerald Cheng, a meteorologist with Environment Canada.

The average temperature in 2019 was 6.4C and in 2018 it was even worse with the average at 3.4C.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not likely to get much better soon,‚Äù Cheng said. ‚ÄúBut we still have the month of May to hope for a good spring.‚Äù

Summer is a bit far off to predict, but the data suggests there should be above normal temperatures.

Look forward to Saturday, which should be sunny and a high of 12C.

It‚Äôs expected to rain on Sunday with a high of 8C. And Monday looks like a mix of sun and cloud with a high of 11C.

title: RAIN, RAIN WON'T GO AWAY: "Real whopper of a system" arrives in T.O.
authors: ['Jane Stevensonmore Jane Stevenson', 'More Jane Stevenson', 'Published', 'January', 'Updated', 'Pm Est Filed Under', 'Toronto Sun', 'News', 'Toronto', 'Gta']
text:
Like they say, when it rains, it pours.

And boy is it ever going to pour in Toronto this weekend.

A major rain storm on ‚Äústeroids‚Äù will start overnight Friday and could leave up to 50 mm of the wet stuff by the time it‚Äôs all over Sunday night.

‚ÄúA real whopper of a system,‚Äù Environment Canada‚Äôs senior climatologist David Phillips said Friday, describing the storm as ‚Äúa significant event.‚Äù

‚ÄúEvery single conceivable weather warning and condition is part of this massive system. It‚Äôs a powerful storehouse of weather even for January,‚Äù he said. ‚Äù It‚Äôs got subtropical moisture from the gulf of Mexico just loaded with moisture and it is coming northward.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe question (for Toronto) is when will it turn to freezing rain? And most of the indications right now are that it will be the evening on Saturday,‚Äù Phillips added.

Environment Canada has issued a special weather statement for Toronto calling it ‚Äúa soaker‚Äù with ‚Äúvery strong southwest winds Sunday.‚Äù

The temperature, meanwhile, is expected to get up to a balmy 11C on Saturday (the record high for Jan. 11 of 11. 7C was set in 1975) before plunging to a high of 2C (still above normal) on Sunday.

The rain is expected to be continuous and heavy at times all day Saturday and into Sunday morning.

‚ÄúThe average we get of rain in Toronto in January would be around 25 mm,‚Äù said Phillips. ‚ÄúSo what we‚Äôre going to get in one day, in one 24-hour period, is going to exceed what we normally get in 31 days.‚Äù

Strong southwest winds are also expected Sunday morning, especially along the Lake Ontario shoreline, with gusts up to 90 km/h.

The Toronto and Region Conservation Authority (TRCA) also issued a statement Thursday saying ‚Äúa flood outlook‚Äù was in effect until Sunday and ‚Äúall shorelines, rivers and streams within the GTA should be considered hazardous,‚Äù and ‚Äúany children or pets should be kept away from any slippery or unstable banks.‚Äù

Meanwhile, the City of Toronto sent out a press release Friday saying ‚ÄúToronto Water‚Äôs storm readiness plan is in place,‚Äù and crews are available 24 hours a day, seven days a week to answer flooding calls at 311.

Otherwise, residents are being asked to clear catch basins on their streets to avoid potential street and basement flooding and ‚Äúmove valuables from basement to shelves or upper floors, and take cleaners, paint or chemicals off the floor as not to further contaminate potential floodwater.‚Äù

They‚Äôre also being told to keep eavestroughs and downspouts clear and shovel any snow or ice away from their foundation and onto their lawn not the road.

jstevenson@postmedia.com

title: The Oakes Hotel
text: About The Oakes Hotel Overlooking the Falls is the only boutique style Fallsview hotel in the city of Niagara Falls, Canada. The hotel provides a front-row-centre view of the Canadian Horseshoe Falls, unmatched by any other hotel in the market. With the best view of any hotel in the Fallsview district, every guest with a Fallsview room or suite will experience the beauty of the falls right outside their window! For guests staying in a River View or Traditional room, check out the 14th floor observation level. If you're looking for a closer view, walk down to the incline railway (located directly in front of the hotel) and take a quick ride down the escarpment, right to the brink of the falls! The Oakes Hotel Overlooking the Falls offers special Premier Collection rooms & suites with the benefit of upgraded amenities, plush white duvets, bathrobes, lavish 4 piece bath and a separate check-in desk. All guests can enjoy a wide range of amenities, including internet access, indoor pool, hot tub, a fitness facility, an onsite Applebees Grill & Bar and an observation level located on the 14th floor.
